title: AB 2716
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 18980 of the Food and Agricultural Code is amended to set the application fee for a livestock meat inspector’s license or processing inspector’s license at $100. Licenses expire at the end of the calendar year and reexamination requires an additional fee. This section is effective until January 1, 2022, unless extended or deleted by a later statute. Section 18981 is also amended. Section 18981 of the Food and Agricultural Code is amended to require a $100 fee for license renewal, with a $25 penalty for late payment. Failure to pay within 90 days of expiration will result in license revocation. This amendment is effective until January 1, 2022, unless extended or deleted by a later statute. Section 19010 of the Food and Agricultural Code requires individuals to submit an application and fee to the secretary before operating a meat processing establishment or custom livestock slaughterhouse. The application fee for a new license is $500 for one year, with licenses expiring on the last day of the calendar year and not prorated. The fee for a license application for a custom livestock slaughterhouse upon a change of ownership is based on the number of livestock slaughtered in the previous year. The section will be repealed on January 1, 2022 unless extended. The renewal fee for a custom livestock slaughterhouse is $500 if 1,000 or fewer livestock were slaughtered in the previous year. The fee for a meat reprocessing establishment renewal is $500. The fee for a custom livestock slaughterhouse renewal is $500 if 1,000 or fewer livestock were slaughtered in the previous year. For slaughterhouses that processed more livestock, the fees vary. Failure to pay the renewal fee within 90 days of expiration will result in license revocation. This section is effective until January 1, 2022, unless extended or repealed by a later statute. Section 24744 of the Food and Agricultural Code amends the application fee for new poultry plants and existing plant ownership changes. The fee is $500 for a new plant license and varies based on the number of poultry slaughtered for existing plants. This section is effective until January 1, 2022, and may be extended or repealed by a later statute. Section 24745 of the Food and Agricultural Code, added in 2011, is repealed. Section 24745 of the Food and Agricultural Code amends the renewal process for poultry plant licenses. The renewal fee varies based on the number of poultry slaughtered, ranging from $500 to $1,200 annually. Section 25053 of the Food and Agricultural Code amends the application fee for a license to be $100. This section will be in effect until January 1, 2022, unless extended or repealed by a later statute. Section 25056 of the Food and Agricultural Code states that applicants for license renewal must pay a $25 penalty if the fee is not paid by the expiration date, with license revocation if not paid within 90 days. This section will be repealed on January 1, 2022, unless extended or deleted by a later statute.
